analyzed: parivāra
translated: The chapter on miscellaneous rules

analyzed: bhikkhu vibhaṅga
translated: The monks’ rules and their analysis

analyzed: dutiya bhāga
translated: The second section

analyzed: samuccayavāra
translated: The summary

original: Methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevanapaccayā kati āpattiyo āpajjati?
analyzed: methunam dhammam paṭisevana paccayā kati āpattiyaḥ āpajjati
translated: How many kinds of offenses does one commit in relation to having sexual intercourse?

original: Methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevanapaccayā catasso āpattiyo āpajjati.🔽Akkhāyite sarīre methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevati, āpatti pārājikassa;
analyzed: methunam dhammam paṭisevana paccayā catassaḥ āpattiyaḥ āpajjati  akkhāyite sarīre methunam dhammam paṭisevati āpatti pārājikassa
translated: One commits four kinds of offenses:🔽if one has sexual intercourse with a visible genitals, one commits an offense entailing expulsion;

original: yebhuyyena khāyite sarīre methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevati, āpatti thullaccayassa;🔽vaṭṭakate mukhe acchupantaṁ aṅgajātaṁ paveseti, āpatti dukkaṭassa;
analyzed: yebhuyyena khāyite sarīre methunam dhammam paṭisevati āpatti thullaccayassa  mukhe acchupantam aṅga jātam paveseti āpatti dukkaṭassa
translated: if one has sexual intercourse with genitals that are mostly visible, one commits a serious offense;🔽if one inserts the penis into a mouth with lips that are drawn back, one commits an offense of wrong conduct;

analyzed: jatumaṭṭhake pācittiya
translated: if one inserts the penis into a penis, one commits an offense entailing confession.

original: methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevanapaccayā imā catasso āpattiyo āpajjati.🔽Tā āpattiyo catunnaṁ vipattīnaṁ kati vipattiyo bhajanti?🔽Sattannaṁ āpattikkhandhānaṁ katihi āpattikkhandhehi saṅgahitā?
analyzed: methunam dhammam paṭisevana paccayā imā catasso āpattiyaḥ āpajjati  tāḥ āpattiyaḥ catunnam vipattīnam kati vipattiyaḥ bhajanti  sattannam āpatti kkhandhānam katihi āpatti kkhandhehi saṅgahitā
translated: One commits these four kinds of offenses in relation to having sexual intercourse.🔽In relation to which of the four kinds of failure are these offenses?🔽Under which of the seven classes of offenses are they found?

analyzed: channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam katihi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhanti
translated: Through how many of the six kinds of origins of offenses do they originate?

analyzed: catunnam adhikaraṇānam katamam
translated: Which of the four kinds of legal issues do they belong to?

analyzed: sattannam samathānam katihi samathehi
translated: Through how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues are they settled?

original: Tā āpattiyo catunnaṁ vipattīnaṁ dve vipattiyo bhajanti—
analyzed: tāḥ āpattiyaḥ catunnam vipattīnam dve vipattiyaḥ bhajanti
translated: Those offenses belong to two of the four kinds of failure:

analyzed: siyā sīla vipattim siyā ācāra vipatti
translated: they may belong to failure in morality, or they may belong to failure in conduct.

analyzed: sattannam āpatti kkhandhānam catūhi āpatti kkhandhehi saṅgahitā
translated: They are found in four of the seven classes of offenses:

original: siyā pārājikāpattikkhandhena, siyā thullaccayāpattikkhandhena, siyā pācittiyāpattikkhandhena, siyā dukkaṭāpattikkhandhena.
analyzed: siyā pārājika āpatti kkhandhena siyā thullaccaya āpatti kkhandhena siyā pācittiya āpatti kkhandhena siyā dukkaṭa āpatti kkhandhena
translated: they may be in the class of offenses entailing expulsion; they may be in the class of serious offenses; they may be in the class of offenses entailing confession; they may be in the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

analyzed: channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam ekena samuṭṭhānena samuṭṭhanti
translated: They originate in one of the six kinds of origins of offenses:

original: kāyato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti, na vācato.
analyzed: kāyataḥ ca cittataḥ ca samuṭṭhanti na vācataḥ
translated: they originate from body and mind, not from speech.

analyzed: āpattādhikaraṇa
translated: They belong to the legal issue of an offense.

analyzed: sattannam samathāna tīhi samathehi
translated: They are settled through three of the seven principles for settling legal issues:

original: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca, paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca …pe….
analyzed: siyā sammukhā vinayena ca paṭiññāta karaṇena ca siyā sammukhā vinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca pe
translated: they may be settled through resolution face-to-face and through acting according to what has been admitted; they may be settled through resolution face-to-face and through covering over as if with grass.

original: Anādariyaṁ paṭicca udake uccāraṁ vā passāvaṁ vā kheḷaṁ vā karaṇapaccayā kati āpattiyo āpajjati?
analyzed: anādariyam paṭicca udake uccāram vā passāvam vā kheḷam vā karaṇa paccayā kati āpattiyaḥ āpajjati
translated: When it comes to passing excrement, urine, or mucus in water out of disrespect, how many kinds of offenses does one commit?

original: Anādariyaṁ paṭicca udake uccāraṁ vā passāvaṁ vā kheḷaṁ vā karaṇapaccayā ekaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: anādariyam paṭicca udake uccāram vā passāvam vā kheḷam vā karaṇa paccayā ekam āpattim āpajjati
translated: When it comes to passing excrement, urine, or mucus in water out of disrespect, one commits one kind of offense:

analyzed: dukkaṭa
translated: an offense of wrong conduct.

original: anādariyaṁ paṭicca udake uccāraṁ vā passāvaṁ vā kheḷaṁ vā karaṇapaccayā imaṁ ekaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: anādariyam paṭicca udake uccāram vā passāvam vā kheḷam vā karaṇa paccayā imam ekam āpattim āpajjati
translated: When it comes to passing excrement, urine, or mucus in water out of disrespect, one commits this one kind of offense.

original: Sā āpatti catunnaṁ vipattīnaṁ kati vipattiyo bhajati?🔽Sattannaṁ āpattikkhandhānaṁ katihi āpattikkhandhehi saṅgahitā?
analyzed: sā āpatti catunnam vipattīnam kati vipattiyaḥ bhajati  sattannam āpatti kkhandhānam katihi āpatti kkhandhehi saṅgahitā
translated: When it comes to this offense, to how many of the four kinds of failure does it belong?🔽Under how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues is it settled?

analyzed: channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam katihi samuṭṭhānehi samuṭṭhāti
translated: Under how many of the six kinds of origins of offenses does it originate?

analyzed: catunnam adhikaraṇānam katamam
translated: To which of the four kinds of legal issues does it belong?

analyzed: sattannam samathānam katihi samathehi sammati
translated: Under how many of the seven principles for settling legal issues is it settled?

original: Sā āpatti catunnaṁ vipattīnaṁ ekaṁ vipattiṁ bhajati—
analyzed: sā āpatti catunnam vipattīnam ekam vipattim bhajati
translated: When it comes to this offense, it belongs to one kind of failure:

analyzed: ācāra vipatti
translated: failure in conduct.

analyzed: sattannam āpatti kkhandhānam ekena āpatti kkhandhena saṅgahitā
translated: It is included under one of the seven classes of offenses:

analyzed: dukkaṭa āpatti kkhandhena
translated: with the class of offenses of wrong conduct.

analyzed: channam āpatti samuṭṭhānānam ekena samuṭṭhānena samuṭṭhāti
translated: It originates from one of the six kinds of origins of offenses:

original: kāyato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhāti, na vācato.
analyzed: kāyataḥ ca cittataḥ ca samuṭṭhāti na vācataḥ
translated: it originates from body and mind, not from speech.

analyzed: āpattādhikaraṇa
translated: It is one of the four kinds of legal issues: legal issues arising from an offense.

analyzed: sattannam samathānam tīhi samathehi sammati
translated: It is settled through one of the seven principles for settling legal issues:

original: siyā sammukhāvinayena ca paṭiññātakaraṇena ca, siyā sammukhāvinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena cāti.
analyzed: siyā sammukhā vinayena ca paṭiññāta karaṇena ca siyā sammukhā vinayena ca tiṇavatthārakena ca ati
translated: it may be settled through resolution face-to-face and through acting according to what has been admitted, or it may be settled through resolution face-to-face and through covering over as if with grass.

analyzed: samuccaya vāraḥ niṭṭhitaḥ aṭṭhamaḥ  aṭṭha paccaya vārā niṭṭhitā
translated: The eighth section on combining is finished.🔽The eight sections on conditions are finished.

analyzed: mahāvibhaṅge soḷasa mahāvārā niṭṭhitā
translated: The sixteen major sections of the detailed explanation are finished.

analyzed: bhikkhu vibhaṅga mahāvāro niṭṭhito
translated: The major section on the Monastic Code for the monks is finished.
